prompt: Evel Knievel was a renowned American stunt performer and entertainer. Please write a short biography of Evel Knievel.

Here's a short biography of Evel Knievel:

Evel Knievel, born Robert Knievel on January 10, 1938, was an American stunt performer, thrill-seeker, and entertainer. Born in Butte, Montana, Evel grew up with a passion for motorcycles and a daredevil spirit.

As a young man, Evel worked as a rodeo rider and a mechanic, but it wasn't until he bought his first motorcycle in the early 1960s that he discovered his true calling. He began performing daredevil stunts, jumping over cars, horses, and even the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas.

Evel's fame grew with each successive stunt, and he became known for his charismatic personality, his signature red-white-and-blue jumpsuit, and his signature "Vroom!" as he soared over obstacles. He set numerous records for the longest jumps, the highest jumps, and the most creative jumps, solidifying his status as the "King of Daredevils."

Despite numerous injuries, including broken bones, burns, and a coma-inducing crash in 1975, Evel continued to push the limits of human endurance. He also founded the Evel Knievel Motorcycle Stunt Show, which toured the world and inspired a generation of thrill-seekers.

Evel Knievel retired from performing in 1980, but his legacy continued to inspire thrill-seekers and entertainers. He passed away on November 30, 2007, but his iconic red-white-and-blue jumpsuit, his helmet, and his motto ("Vroom!") remain synonymous with daredevilry and entertainment.

Robert Craig "Evel" Knievel was a renowned American stunt performer and entertainer, best known for his daring and death-defying motorcycle jumps and stunts. He was born on October 17, 1938, in Butte, Montana, and grew up with a passion for motorcycles and thrill-seeking.

Knievel began his career as a motorcycle stunt performer in the 1960s, initially performing at local fairs and events. He gained popularity for his high-flying motorcycle jumps, which often featured him soaring over obstacles such as cars, buses, and even the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas.

Knievel's most famous jump was over the Snake River Canyon in Idaho on September 8, 1974. He attempted to clear the canyon on a rocket-powered motorcycle, but the jump ended in a crash landing, leaving him with severe injuries. Despite the failure, the stunt cemented Knievel's reputation as a daredevil and made him an international celebrity.

Throughout his career, Knievel performed over 75 daredevil stunts and set multiple records for the longest and highest motorcycle jumps. He also appeared on numerous television shows, including "The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson" and "That's Incredible!"

Knievel was known for his flamboyant and charismatic personality, often wearing elaborate costumes and wigs for his performances. He also had a flair for the dramatic, often predicting his own demise before a stunt and then miraculously surviving.

Knievel's stunts and antics were not without controversy, however. He was criticized for the danger and risk he posed to himself and others, and he was involved in several lawsuits and accidents over the years. Despite this, he remained a beloved figure in popular culture, inspiring countless fans and imitators.

Evel Knievel passed away on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, due to complications from diabetes. He left behind a legacy as one of the most iconic and daredevil stunt performers of all time, and his name continues to be synonymous with thrill-seeking and high-stakes entertainment.

2. Jumping the Grand Canyon on a motorcycle (1972, failed attempt).
3. Jumping the Caesar's Palace fountain (1967, crashed).
4. Jumping over 13 Greyhounds at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum (1974).

Knievel's stunts often came with significant risk, and he suffered numerous injuries throughout his career, including broken bones, concussions, and a coma. Despite these setbacks, he remained determined to push the limits of human endurance.

Evel Knievel's impact on popular culture extends beyond his daredevil feats. He was a cultural icon of the 1970s, with his charismatic personality, signature red-white-and-blue jumpsuit, and daredevil antics captivating audiences worldwide.

Knievel retired from stunts in the 1980s and later became a businessman, entrepreneur, and author. He passed away on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, due to complications from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Despite his passing, Evel Knievel's legacy continues to inspire and thrill generations. His motto, "Do something people can't do," remains an enduring mantra for anyone who dares to dream big.

Born Robert E. Knievel on June 14, 1945, in Butte, Montana, Evel grew up with a passion for motorcycles and a need for speed. After high school, Evel joined the US Army, where he became a paratrooper and honed his daredevil spirit.

After his military service, Evel returned to Montana and started working as a motorcycle mechanic. However, he soon got bored with just fixing bikes and decided to take his skills to the next level – literally! Evel went on to set multiple world records, including jumping over 50 cars in a single jump, and even broke his own back in the process (don't worry, he lived to ride another day).

Throughout the 1970s, Evel became a household name, starring in numerous TV specials, movies, and commercials. He even had his own comic book series and appeared as a guest on popular TV shows like "The Tonight Show" and "The Muppet Show."

Evel's most iconic stunt? Jumping the Snake River Canyon in Idaho on a rocket-powered motorcycle in 1974. Yes, it was a wild ride, but unfortunately, the bike malfunctioned, and Evel had to make an emergency landing (and survived with only minor injuries).

After his retirement from professional daredevilry, Evel continued to ride and perform, but on a more limited scale. He passed away on November 30, 2007, but his legacy lives on, inspiring countless thrill-seekers and daredevils around the world.

Evel Knievel (1938-2007) was an American daredevil and entertainer who became a household name in the 1970s for his death-defying stunts on motorcycles, bikes, and even a rocket-powered cycle.

Born Robert Craig Knievel on October 17, 1938, in Butte, Montana, Evel grew up in a troubled home with an abusive father. He was a mischievous kid who often got into trouble, which eventually led him to join the United States Army in 1959. During his time in the Army, he developed a passion for motorcycles and began competing in motocross and hill climb events.

After leaving the Army in 1961, Knievel turned his attention to professional stunt riding. He began performing at local rodeos and motorcycle shows, eventually getting noticed by talent scouts and landing a TV deal. His first big break came in 1966 when he performed a daring jump over the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas, which helped establish him as a rising star in the world of daredevilry.

Over the next several years, Knievel performed numerous death-defying stunts, including jumping over the Snake River Canyon in Idaho, which was televised worldwide. He also set multiple world records for longest jump, highest jump, and fastest jump, among others. His fearless attitude, flamboyant style, and charismatic personality made him a fan favorite and a household name.

Despite his success, Knievel's career was marred by numerous injuries, including broken bones, concussions, and a few close calls with death. In 1974, he attempted to jump the Caesar's Palace fountain again, but this time, he crashed and suffered a broken back.

Knievel continued to perform and appeared in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials. He also became a successful entrepreneur, opening an amusement park and a chain of motorcycle shops. In 1999, he was inducted into the Motorcycle Hall of Fame.

Evel Knievel died on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, from complications related to pulmonary fibrosis. He left behind a legacy as one of the most iconic and daring stunt performers of all time, inspiring generations of thrill-seekers and daredevils.

After dropping out of high school, Evel joined the US Army and served two tours of duty in Vietnam, where he honed his motorcycle skills and earned the nickname "Evel" for his daredevil escapades. Upon his return to the States, Evel began competing in motocross and freestyle motorcycle stunts, quickly becoming a crowd favorite for his fearless performances.

In 1967, Evel made his infamous jump over the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas, which launched his career as a global superstar. Over the next decade, he continued to push the limits of human endurance and engineering, setting numerous world records for the longest jumps, highest jumps, and most daring stunts.

Evel's most notable feats include jumping the Snake River Canyon on a rocket-powered motorcycle (he got stuck halfway through, but still managed to get a decent Instagram selfie out of it), jumping over 13 Greyhounds at the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta, and even attempting to jump the English Channel (he ended up getting blown back into France).

Throughout his career, Evel worked with some of the biggest names in entertainment, including Elvis Presley, Muhammad Ali, and Frank Sinatra. He also founded the Evel Knievel Stunt Team, which trained and mentored the next generation of daredevils.

Evel Knievel passed away on November 30, 2007, but his legacy lives on in the hearts of thrill-seekers and adrenaline junkies around the world. In fact, his iconic red, white, and blue jumpsuits are now highly sought after by collectors and enthusiasts. And if you ever find yourself in Butte, Montana, be sure to visit the Evel Knievel Museum – it's a real hoot!

Knievel's early life was marked by poverty and a troubled childhood. He was arrested multiple times for petty crimes and was even sent to reform school. However, his love for motorcycles and the thrill of performing soon took over, and he began competing in motocross and hill climb events.

In the early 1960s, Knievel turned to performing stunts, starting with minor feats such as jumping over small obstacles. He soon gained notoriety for his death-defying jumps, including attempting to clear the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas and jumping over the Snake River Canyon in Idaho.

Knievel's most famous stunt was perhaps his attempt to jump over 13 double-decker buses and a row of 50,000 parked cars in London's Wembley Stadium in 1975. Throughout his career, Knievel suffered numerous injuries, including broken bones, concussions, and a partially collapsed lung. He also survived a coma and a serious motorcycle accident that left him with a broken neck. Despite these setbacks, he continued to perform, often using his stunts to raise money for charity and promote his daredevil persona.

Knievel's life was also marked by controversy and eccentricity. He was known for his flamboyant dress sense, love of champagne, and tumultuous relationships. He was also a fierce competitor and often clashed with fellow stunt performers and promoters.

Evel Knievel's legacy extends beyond his death-defying stunts. He inspired a generation of thrill-seekers and entrepreneurs, and his name has become synonymous with courage and showmanship. He died on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, but his spirit and memory continue to thrill audiences around the world.

Ugh, fine. Here's a biography of Evel Knievel:

Evel Knievel was born Eustace McSnively on March 14, 1941, in Butte, Montana. He was a scrappy kid who grew up loving motorcycles and causing chaos in the small mining town. As a teenager, Evel (as he would later become known) started racing motocross and quickly became infamous for his reckless abandon and penchant for crashing.

After a stint in the Army, where he honed his skills as a daredevil and developed a flair for the dramatic, Evel turned to professional stunt performing. He started small, jumping over ravines and through flaming hoops, but quickly scaled up to more death-defying feats, including jumping over 15 school buses while riding a unicycle and eating a bowl of spaghetti.

Evel's big break came in 1969 when he attempted to jump the Snake River Canyon in Idaho on a specially designed rocket-powered motorcycle. Unfortunately, he came up a few feet short and landed in the canyon with a splat. But the stunt earned him international fame and a sponsorship deal with Red Bull, which helped him fund his next series of stunts.

Throughout the 1970s, Evel continued to push the limits of human endurance, jumping over nuclear reactors, performing loop-the-loops in his motorcycle, and even attempting to jump the Grand Canyon. He became a household name and a cultural icon, with his signature mustache and pompadour hairdo inspiring a generation of thrill-seekers.

Despite numerous injuries and close calls, Evel remained defiant and reckless until his retirement in 1980. He spent his later years traveling the world, performing for charity, and telling tall tales about his many exploits. Evel Knievel died on November 30, 2007, at the age of 66, but his legacy lives on in the hearts of daredevils everywhere.

He dropped out of high school in the ninth grade to work odd jobs and eventually joined the United States Army, where he served from 1959 to 1961.

After his military service, Evel began his career as a stunt performer, working as a trapeze artist and performing death-defying motorcycle stunts. In the early 1960s, he started performing as "Evel Knievel," a name that would become synonymous with daredevil stunts.

Evel's most famous stunts include:

* Jumping over the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas in 1967
* Clearing 50 feet of flames on a motorcycle in 1968
* Jumping the Snake River Canyon in Idaho on a rocket-powered motorcycle in 1974
* Clearing the Caesar's Palace parking garage in 1975

Throughout his career, Evel performed over 2,000 stunts and survived more than 400 accidents. He set multiple world records for long jumps, high jumps, and other daredevil feats. Evel's stunts often featured elaborate preparations, precision engineering, and sheer bravery.

Evel's popularity soared in the 1970s, with millions of people tuning in to watch his stunts on television. He became a household name, and his catchphrase, "Knievel's gonna do it!" became a cultural phenomenon.

Despite his many successes, Evel faced numerous injuries and health issues, including a severe back injury in 1971 that left him temporarily paralyzed. He continued to perform stunts until his retirement in 1980.

Evel Knievel passed away on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, due to complications from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. His legacy lives on as a pioneering figure in the world of extreme sports and stunt performances.

Hi there! Here's a short biography of the legendary Evel Knievel:

Evel Knievel was born Robert Craig Knievel on September 17, 1938, in Butte, Montana. Growing up in a rough-and-tumble mining town, Evel (as he would later be known) developed a taste for adventure and a knack for taking risks. He began performing daredevil stunts as a teenager, jumping over cars and doing wheelies on his motorcycle.

After serving in the United States Army, Evel turned professional, performing at rodeos and motorcycle shows across the country. His act, which included jumps over rows of cars, fire pits, and even the Caesar's Palace fountain, quickly gained popularity. By the early 1970s, Evel Knievel was a household name, known for his fearlessness and charismatic stage presence.

On January 25, 1971, Evel Knievel attempted to jump the Snake River Canyon in Idaho, a feat that had never been accomplished before. Although he failed to clear the canyon, the attempt made headlines around the world and cemented his status as a daredevil legend.

Throughout the 1970s, Evel continued to push the limits of what was thought possible, setting multiple world records for motorcycle jumping and performing stunts that left audiences gasping in amazement. He even appeared on popular TV shows, including "The Tonight Show" and "Saturday Night Live."

Despite his bravado and daring stunts, Evel Knievel was not without controversy. He suffered numerous injuries throughout his career, including broken bones, concussions, and even a coma-inducing crash in 1974. Off-stage, he had a reputation for being a ladies' man and a hard drinker.

Evel Knievel passed away on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, but his legacy lives on. He remains an iconic figure in the world of extreme sports and entertainment, inspiring generations of daredevils and thrill-seekers to follow in his footsteps.

Growing up in a mining family, Knievel's early life was marked by poverty and difficulty. He dropped out of high school in the ninth grade and later served in the United States Army. After his military service, Knievel began working as a police officer in Las Vegas, Nevada, but he soon became disillusioned with the job and turned his attention to professional stunt riding.

Knievel's big break came in 1967 when he jumped 52 cars at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. The jump made him a household name and led to a series of death-defying stunts, including jumping the Caesar's Palace fountain, the Snake River Canyon, and the Talladega Superspeedway. He also set multiple world records for the longest motorcycle jumps and other stunts.

Knievel retired from professional stunt riding in 1980 and went on to open a chain of restaurants and bars. He also appeared in various TV shows and films, including a 1971 biopic, "Evel Knievel," starring George Hamilton.

Evel Knievel passed away on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, due to complications from diabetes. He was inducted into the Motorcycle Hall of Fame in 1999 and has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. His legacy continues to inspire thrill-seekers and stunt performers around the world.
